data.title: Meet the candidates for Hattiesburg's Ward 5
data.meta_description: Two Democrats will vie in the primary for the opportunity to face off against incumbent Naylor in the general election.
data.text:
Two Democratic candidates will face off in the May 2 primary race for Hattiesburg City Council Ward 5 for the opportunity to advance to the June 6 general election.

The winner of the primary between Nicholas R. Brown and Jennifer-Brown Travis will face incumbent Ward 5 Councilman Henry Naylor in the general election. Naylor, who is running as an independent, is seeking his fifth term in the post.

A questionnaire was given to the candidates. They were asked to provide basic biographical information, as well as answer three questions.

Nicholas R. Brown

Age:34

Political party:Democrat

Political experience: None

Occupation: Owner at Brown Lawn Service, LLC. I am also a substitute teacher with the Hattiesburg Public School District.

Education: Bachelor of Science in business administration with an emphasis in management information systems

Family: My father and mother are Frank and Josie Brown. My sister is Monique Brown. My wife of 7 years is Evette Taylor Brown, and I have a 3-year-old son, Nicholas Brown Jr.

What qualifies you to run for this position? My roots in Ward 5 go back two generations, starting with my late grandmother, Elice Bridges, who helped many people during her life. My parents continued that legacy of service to the community. They instilled within me a burning desire to be a blessing to others.

I definitely feel that I'm a product of the entire village. My education and work foundation shaped me into the hard worker, critical thinker, and problem-solver Christian man who can live up to the trust and responsibilities of being chosen by the citizens to lead Ward 5. I'm also a people person that care about the community, and I want to help in getting things done in Ward 5. Ward 5 needs adequate resources.

If elected, what specific ideas do you have in mind to improve your particular ward? When elected, we will all need to be on the same page in order to get things done properly. There are a lot of open ditches that need to be tended to in Ward 5. There also needs to be a plan in action to develop more sidewalks, improve lighting in some areas, replace old water and sewer pipes, fixing roads, and making sure that city property is well maintained.

We also need some strong mentorship and tutorial programs for the youth. I plan on working close with the other council members and mayor to secure a tight budget and proper school funding.

What challenges do you expect to see in the upcoming term? The challenges that I see in the upcoming term are getting the school funding back on track and coming up with a plan to to update our current infrastructure.

Jennifer Brown-Travis

Age: 48

Political party: Democratic

Political experience: Currently serves a Forrest County District 3 Constable

Education: 1986 graduate of Hattiesburg High School; 1986-1988 Pearl River Community College

Family: Mother: Bobbie Brown-Bullock. Husband: Gregory Travis. Children: Jen-Na Brujae Brown, Ju'ma Vanchez Martin and Jazmine Mo-Ney Martin

What qualifies you to run for this position? I am a resident of Ward 5. I care about my community, I will make Ward 5 a priority, we need equal city services as the rest of Hattiesburg.

If elected, what specific ideas do you have in mind to improve your particular ward? Infrastructure ... Streets, sidewalks, playground.

Education is very important. I will work hand-in-hand with the schools to improve the floor plan of our youth. The children are our future. Accessibility is very important, and I would be available for you to contact me and you can trust that I will get back to you in a timely manner.

What challenges do you expect to see in the upcoming term? I would like for the council to work together as a TEAM (Together Everyone Achieves More) to make the whole Hattiesburg greater. Ward 5, you have been looking for someone who is different, someone who will stand up, speak out and move Ward 5 forward, well her name is Jennifer BROWN-Travis.

Henry Naylor

Age: 62

Political party: Independent

Political experience: Actively involved in national, state and local politics since 1979. Helped with the process in 1984 in Hattiesburg to change the form of local government from a mayor/commissioner form of government to a mayor/council form. Was asked by Gov. Ronnie Musgrove and agreed to serve as the Mississippi State Coordinating Campaign Manager for Vice President Al Gore and Sen. Joe Lieberman 2000 presidential campaign. Four terms as Ward 5 Councilman.

Education: Attended Forrest County and Hattiesburg public schools, graduate of Hattiesburg High School and graduate of USM with a B.S. in communications.

Occupation: Project coordinator/consultant

Family: Dr. Wanda K. Naylor (wife), married for 37 years. Henry Jr. (son), Kelly (daughter), Harmonie and Aubrey (granddaughters)

What qualifies you to run for this position? Created a system and programs for community development in city government. Established a city-wide task force and neighborhood contacts. Organized neighborhood improvement associations and set up education and training workshop for residents of Hattiesburg. Organized crime prevention programs throughout the city.

Developed a resource bank through research and investigation. Identified neighborhood needs, problems and characteristics through survey development; results used for neighborhood revitalization. Coordinated programs and worked cooperatively with city divisions and private sector agencies and organizations for overall neighborhood and community improvement.

Established, implemented and helped manage a sound program of community development based on good planning principles. Cleared homeowners and small businesses for renovations and additions on private property. Addressed complaints from residents and small businesses as it related to code enforcement.

If elected, what specific ideas do you have in mind to improve your particular ward? Continue to work with all significant others (mayor, council,and constituents) toward addressing primary concerns, particularly public safety, public schools, environmental and perceived pay disparity amongst city employees.
